entry.title: Interesting Thingys #19
entry.content:
Long time no see, this week links from our nearly forgotten category physics

GIT

  • Git undo last commit - Stack Overflow

HTML5

  • O'Reilly - HTML5 may be winning the war against apps - O'Reilly Radar

Ruby

  • Unlimited Novelty: Ruby is faster than Python, PHP, and Perl
  • Getting Down To Earth: Geospatial Analysis With Rails - Daniel Azuma - RailsConf 2012 and the RailsConf 2012 Talk Notes | Daniel Azuma with tons of links.

Javascript

  • Fluent 2012: Brendan Eich, "JavaScript at 17" - YouTube
  • Dependency management with RequireJS | Adobe Developer Connection
  • timbre - JavaScript Library for Objective Sound Programming
  • ECMAScript 6 Resources For The Curious JavaScripter
  • Self-updating scripts | High Performance Web Sites
  • Destroy Today / 10 reasons why I switched to Spine.js
  • jQuery++
  • gmaps.js — the easiest way to use Google Maps
  • Your first node.js module - Connor Montgomery

CSS

  • The single responsibility principle applied to CSS — CSS Wizardry—CSS, Web Standards, Typography, and Grids by Harry Roberts
  • Understanding the CSS Transforms Matrix - Dev.Opera
  • Responsive Mode and Layout View in Firefox 15 // by Paul Rouget
  • The Tilde is an Amazing CSS Selector. - Nicholson Web Software
  • Eric's Archived Thoughts: Gradient Repetition

Vim

  • Vim Eastereggs
  • vim-scripts/Shebang

Mobile

  • Creating native-like user experiences in PhoneGap with App-UI | Adobe Developer Connection

Productivity

  • Learn Shortcuts. Vim Commands, Command Line, Unix Commands, Sublime Keys, TextMate Keys, Emacs Keys

Databases

  • MySQL is done. It's the Postgres Age. by Jeff Dickey

Performance

  • Twitter Engineering: Improving performance on twitter.com
  • Client-Side vs. Server-Side Rendering

Programming

  • Code Reviews that might actually work — Write More Tests
  • Erlang in production: "I wish I'd known that when I started" - Bernard Duggan - YouTube

Other

  • 7 Habits of Highly Effective Hackers: Using twitter to build password cracking wordlist
  • Hacker News Rankings

Hosting / Server / SPDY

  • SPDY Review from Martin Nilsson
  • Firefox now supports SPDY by default

Physics

  • The Second Copernican Revolution: Our Changing View of Our Place in the Universe - YouTube
  • Minute Physics - Picture of the Big Bang (aka Oldest Light in the Universe)
  • Big Bang Registry

Fun

  • The world's worst password requirements list

entry.title: Interesting Thingys #18
entry.content:
This week we have two new categories in the list: Objective-C and Clojure

Objective-C

  • mpospese / MPFoldTransition
    MPFoldTransition is a set of classes to add folding-style transitions to iOS 5 projects.

GIT

  • Better READMEs for GitHub Forks
  • Exploring Expressions of Emotions in GitHub Commit Messages
    An extensive analysis of emotions in Github commit messages

Ruby

  • schneems / sextant
    Show routes in your Rails app while working in development. Visit http://localhost:3000/rails/routes and you'll see an output similar to rake routes.
  • Building Streaming REST APIs with Ruby

Javascript

  • requestAnimationFrame API: now with sub-millisecond precision
    1/60s == 16.666667 ms therefore we need a sub-millisecond precision to match the monitor framerate

CSS

  • The shapes of CSS
    shapes solely done in CSS

Vim

  • Ben Orenstein - Write code faster: expert-level vim (Railsberry 2012) [video]

Other

  • Markdown here
    Write your email in Markdown, then make it pretty. Markdown Here lets you write email in Markdown and render it before sending.
  • Command Line and User Friendliness
  • Improving performance on twitter.com
  • Ping times between cities

Programming

  • Why our code smells [presentation]
    Odors are communication devices. They exist for a reason and are usually trying to tell us something.
  • Latency numbers every programmer should know [gist]

Hosting / Server / SPDY

  • Uptime
    A simple HTTP remote monitoring utility using Node.js and MongoDB.

Fun

  • Kintinuous Color
    An extension to our Kintinuous: Spatially Extended KinectFusion system showing real-time fused colored mesh volume generation.

entry.title: Interesting Thingys #17
entry.content:
This week we have two new categories in the list: Objective-C and Clojure

Objective-C

  • NSRails
    an Objective-C framework for ActiveRecord like API (crud remote rails objects).

GIT

  • Github for Windows
    The famous Mac tool is now ported to Windows

Ruby

  • Ruby 1.9 lands NaCl support, can run in Chrome
  • twitter / activerecord-reputation-system
    The Active Record Reputation System helps you discover more about your application and make better decisions.
  • Three quick Rails console tips
    Dive into your app / Try out a helper / Where does that method come from?

Clojure

  • Reducers
    A Library and Model for Collection Processing

HTML5

  • sipml5
    The world's first HTML5 SIP client. Written in pure JavaScript.
  • WYSIHTML5
    A better approach to rich text editing
  • WebGL 80.000 particles
    Cool WebGL demo with 80.000 particles. Kinda rocks!

Javascript

  • 10 reasons why I switched to Spine.js
  • CPU Profiling with Nodetime
    Introduction to nodetime a profiler for nodejs apps
  • Moment.js
    A lightweight (4.3k) JavaScript library for displaying and manipulating dates and times. E.g.: last Saturday at 6:25. Includes I18N support.
  • Self-updating scripts - Steve Souders

CSS

  • The Tilde is an Amazing CSS Selector

Linux

  • Linux 3.4
    has been released. Offical announcement

Windows

  • Building the next generation file system for Windows: ReFS
    extensive article on Windows 8's new file system ReFS

Vim

  • Learn Vimscript the Hard Way - by Steve Losh
    Steve Losh is not unknown to the Vim community. His .vimrc was the starting point for many Vim noobs. Learn Vimscript the Hard Way is a short book for users of the Vim editor who want to learn how to customize Vim.

Databases

  • PostgreSQL vs MongoDB
    A comparative tests of postgresql vs mongodb and the HackerNews Discussion
  • Intro to Graph Databases [video]
    A high level introduction to graph databases. This webinar demonstrates how graph databases fit within the NOSQL space, and where they are most appropriately used.
  • Map reduce questions and answers part 1 and part 2

Browser

  • Google Chrome overtakes Internet Explorer as the Web’s most used browser
    Google Chrome has been long expected to leapfrog Microsoft’s Internet Explorer (IE) to take its position as the Web’s most used browser and, according to data from Statcounter, the momentous change of leadership happened last week.

Other

  • The Facebook Offering: How It Compares
  • Disposable Email address
    A comparison of disposable email addresses and email forwarding services.
  • The best story in development
    Not completely tech related but still worth noting: Africa is experiencing some of the biggest falls in child mortality ever seen, anywhere.
  • Ask HN: Favorite HN threads of all time
    Cellis asks: Have any Hacker News threads ever truly changed your perspective on life, or technology? Post them please.

Programming

  • 10 ways to improve your programming skills
    nearly a year old, but still valid points.

Hosting / Server / SPDY

  • Nginx 1.3.0
  • peterkeen / dokuen
    Heroku for the masses

entry.title: Interesting Thingys #16
entry.content:
This week a potpourri of tech topics…

GIT

  • Geohub - locate your github buddies on a map
  • Gitspective - A different perspective of a Github User - create a Facebook like timeline of your Github account

Ruby

  • marshally / rspec-rails-uncommitted - rake tasks for rails-3 which selectively run specs based on your SCM status. What a great idea.
  • The Bastards Book of Ruby - A Programming Primer for Counting and Other Unconventional Tasks

HTML5

  • Responsive Images and Web Standards at the Turning Point
  • sindresorhus / screenfull.js - Simple wrapper for cross-browser usage of the JavaScript Fullscreen API.

Javascript

  • jQuery Knob - knobs for the masses

CSS

  • CSS Arrow - Generate the CSS for a tooltip arrow.
  • SASS vs. LESS - "Which CSS preprocessor language should I choose?" is a hot topic lately.

Mac

  • TwUI - TwUI is a hardware accelerated UI framework for Mac, inspired by UIKit
  • Dash - snippet manager and documentation browser, supports lots of programming languages and snippets can be sync via a Dropbox folder.

Browser

  • Chrome supports TCP & UDP Sockets
  • Websocket Frame Inspection now in Chrome DevTools

Other

  • Vert.x: Why the JVM May Put Node.js on the Ropes - Vert.x is the framework for the next generation of asynchronous, effortlessly scalable, concurrent applications.
  • Free Language Agnostic Programming Books - A comprehensive list of free books collected at stackoverflow

Hosting / Server / SPDY

  • OpenShift - RedHat's answer to Heroku
  • Nginx - Upcoming SPDY support details
  • SPDY performance on mobile networks - I alwaysb thought that SPDY will imporve page load times on mobile platforms, here is the proof.

Videos / Talks / Books

  • Seven Databases in Seven Weeks - A Guide to Modern Databases and the NoSQL Movement now in print

entry.title: Interesting Thingys #15
entry.content:
This week with highlights from JavaScript, HTML5, Ruby, …

GIT

  • Git website has a new design

Ruby

  • Multiple Ruby Version Support on Heroku
  • Five common Rails mistakes - Mike Perham
  • How to get 4x the performance out of Heroku with Unicorn

HTML5

  • Polyfills for the Pragmatist
  • Beyond HTML5: Device API's & PhoneGap with Brian Leroux'
  • BBC News - Coding the future: HTML5 takes the internet by storm

Javascript

  • Better code optimization decisions for V8
  • adobe / brackets - An open source code editor for the web, written in JavaScript, HTML and CSS.
  • Physijs - a physics engine for three.js, check out the demos
  • Cueppoint.JS - A plugin for adding cue-points and subtitles to HTML5 Video
  • New Draft Specification for ES.next (Ecma-262 Edition 6)
  • Proxies and Frozen objects
  • Dynamo JS - kind of irritating

CSS

  • Viewport Sized Typography | CSS-Tricks
  • Making a move with CSS3 animations - Dev.Opera

Linux

  • E4RAT - Improving Startup Times by Physical Block Reallocation

Search

  • SwiftType - Let's you integrate an external search to your website. The demo video looks promising.

Security

  • How To Safely Store A Password

Productivity

  • The Haskell / Snap ecosystem is as productive (or more) than Ruby/Rails.

Videos / Talks

  • Node.js in Context with Jason Hoffman of Joyent
  • JavaScript Primitive Types vs Reference Types

Fun

  • Recursive Drawing
